doc.title: Week of September 1-5
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM/Euro areaEuro area_2025-08-29

passages.text: - French government likely to fall back fiscal consolidation to remain on track- National reports point to a modest increase in core inflation in August- For now, ECB commentary does not suggest a clear bias to consider another rate cut

This week started with a focus on French politics. French Prime Minister Bayrou is poised to lose a vote of confidence in the lower house, likely followed by President Macron appointing a new Prime Minister. New lower house elections cannot be ruled out, but what remains very unlikely is that Macron himself resigns. Still, the fiscal implications look manageable. Bayrou had proposed a 2026 budget with a fiscal tightening of \(0.9\%\) of GDP, significantly more than the \(0.5\%\) of GDP required by the EU's fiscal rules. We had projected a tightening of \(0.4\%\) of GDP and that remains a reasonable outcome. The Left coalition is unlikely to emerge as winner, should new elections be held, while the far-right RN has dropped many of its fiscal demands and has stressed the importance of adhering to the EU's fiscal rules. This likely reflects nervousness about triggering market fallout ahead of the 2027 presidential election.
Figure 1: Sovereign bond spreads %-pt spread to 10yr German bond yields

In line with this view, markets sent only a modest signal this week, widening the spread to German bunds by just 10bp from tight levels (Figure 1). The region has come a long way from the days when a weaker institutional setting, a lack of (conditional) support mechanisms, and more fundamental challenges to fiscal orthodoxy resulted in more extreme markets pressures and spillovers across countries. Today, the mere possibility of market pressure appears sufficient to encourage most political parties to commit to sustainable fiscal trajectories, coupled with broader reforms. Crucially, even most nonmainstream parties are keenly aware that countries qualify for the various ECB bond market programs only if they have made such commitments as a precondition. In this sense, the region has moved from a bad equilibrium to a good one, with
markets exerting a disciplining function without an actual tightening in financial conditions.

The ECB held rates in July and suggested that policy rates was in a "good place" at \(2\%\) . This created the impression that the data need to give the ECB a push for a cut to be considered. The PMI rose modestly in August and is not providing that pressure, even though the ECB staff's projections require the PMI to increase further into the autumn. That puts the near- term focus on the inflation data.

This week's national inflation reports suggest that Euro area core inflation may decline \(0.1\% - \mathrm{pt}\) to \(2.2\%\) oya, verus our original expectation of a larger decline to \(2.1\%\) oya (Figure 2). However, even that smaller decline would leave the annual rate of core inflation very close to the ECB's target and would imply a monthly increase in core prices in the middle of the \(0.1 - 0.2\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , sa, range. Combined with last month's increase of \(0.19\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , sa, and the two softer releases before that, it would leave recent core price momentum at or below the ECB's target, albeit with some noise. In addition, we expect only a modest \(0.21\% \mathrm{m / m}\) , sa, increase in services prices, which would seem consistent with the slowing in wage inflation. More surprisingly, core goods inflation appears to have picked up recently, despite the clear downward pressures from the stronger currency and the threat of Chinese trade diversion effects. If those core goods pressures fade in the next few months, it would help to pull core inflation below the ECB target.
Figure 2: Euro area core inflation

With US tariffs on EU goods having increased sharply and uncertainty around US trade policy still elevated, the lack of a clear impact on economic sentiment remains a puzzle. This week's EC survey did show a decline, but this was modest, unwound only part of July's increase, and left the survey broadly aligned with the PMI's signal of trend- like growth (Figure 3). The resilience of retail confidence is also noteworthy, relative to the weaker level of consumer confidence (Fig
ure 4). Actual consumption has tended to outperform the signal from consumer confidence recently.
Figure 3: Euro area business surveys
Figure 4: Euro area economic sentiment Standard deviation from 2000-07 average
Source: European Commission, J.P.Morgan

Euro area unemployment has been remarkably stable at record lows, despite an ongoing softening in the German labor market. However, the latest report for August showed a modest improvement. Unemployment fell for the first time since the end of 2022 (Figure 5).
Figure 5: German unemployment

Employment also ticked back up \((+4,000)\) in July, after two consecutive declines. Vacancies are still moving lower, but short- time work subsidy applications have slowed somewhat and actual usage of the scheme (on a full- time equivalent basis) has declined. In addition, the business surveys (PMI, IFO) and the IAB barometer are pointing to a modest

improvement in the labor market from recent months. The changes are modest, but the direction is constructive and could reflect a turn in fiscal policy combined with the gradually improving expectations that this generates.

This week's M3 report was constructive, but did not validate fears of hawkish ECB Governing Council members that the current policy rate is already in accommodative territory. Bank lending to the real economy increased by €20bn in July, but this marked a slowing from the recent trend of \(3\%\) at around \(2.5\%\) . This is consistent with an economy that is growing at around trend, rather than accelerating above it. Similarly, car registrations have been stable at a low level in recent months, rather than showing any credit- driven pickup. Of course, structural issues may be impacting the demand for cars, given the transition to EVs. However, bank lending for house purchase has also not accelerated further recently and is therefore still a tick below a \(3\%\) (Figure 7).
Figure 6: Euro area bank lending to real economy
Source: ECB, J.P. Morgan
Figure 7: Euro area bank lending to households
Source: ECB, J.P. Morgan

The 2Q Euro area GDP print should be revised down a little,from 0.5%q/q saar to 0.2%, after a 2.2% ar gain in 1Q.Excluding Ireland, we expect a downward revision to 0.4% ar after a 1.1% ar gain in 1Q. The volatility in 1H was linked to front loading related to the tariff war. Through the noise, GDP ex. Ireland has been growing at an average 0.7% ar pace in 1H, broadly in line with the signal of the PMI. Survey data in 3Q are pointing to a slightly firmer pace of growth of 1% ar.At the component level, the 2Q Euro area data should post a strong gain for inventories offset by a large drag from net trade. For domestic final sales, we expect the data to show a modest private consumption gain and stronger government consumption, while investment should decline a little.

See main text. We expect Euro area headline inflation to have increased by a tenth in August while we expect Euro area core inflation to have declined by a tenth. At the country level (in CPI terms except for Italy) core inflation was stable in Germany (2.7%), Italy (2.0%), and Portugal (2.5%), while it declined in France (-0.3%-pt to 1.4%oya) and Belgium (-0.1%-pt to 2.3%oya), and increased a tenth in Spain 2.4%. A one-tenth decline in Euro area core inflation to 2.2%oya would be consistent with seasonally adjusted core prices running towards the middle of a 0.1-0.2%m/m range in August, leaving core running close to a 2.0% ar pace in the last two months.
Source: European Commission, Eurostat, ECB, FSO, Bundesbank, IFO, INSEE, ISAE, Istat, INE, CBS, BNB, Markit, and J.P. Morgan forecasts

1Q252Q25Final 2Q25Italy (final)%q/q, sa0.3-0.1-0.1%q/q, saar1.21.3-0.3%oya0.70.40.4GDP components (%q/q saar)Private consumption1.00.9-0.2Government consumption-1.3-1.00.7Fixed investment6.44.44.2Exports11.58.8-6.8Imports11.05.11.7Contribution to GDP growth (%q/q saar)Domestic final sales1.71.31.0Inventories-1.0-1.31.4Net trade0.51.2-2.7

The final release from Istat confirmed that the Italian economy contracted by 0.3%q/q saar in 2Q25, following a 1.3%q/q saar gain in 1Q25. The underlying details, released for the first time, revealed a significant drag from net exports (-2.7%-pts contribution) following a surge in 1Q25, primarily driven by the frontloading of sales to the US. An increase in inventories (+1.4%-pts cont.), which had been depleted in 1Q25 to satisfy export demand, only partially offset this drag. But the weak figures were also underpinned by subdued domestic demand (+1%-pt contr.) amid elevated uncertainty and downbeat sentiment, particularly among households, despite ongoing strength in the labor market and real income growth. Private consumption (-0.2%q/q saar) has broadly stagnated after three quarters of modest growth. Meanwhile, investment remained steady (+4.2%q/q saar), as gross fixed capital formation continued to be supported by Next Generation EU investments. But it is also noteworthy that residential investment continued to hold up, increasing by 2.5%q/q saar, despite the end of the Superbonus. A rebound in government consumption (+0.7%q/q saar) also played some role in offsetting the trade drag and weakness in private consumption.

A one-tenth decline in Euro area core inflation to 2.2%oya would be consistent with seasonally adjusted core prices running towards the middle of a 0.1-0.2%m/m range in August, leaving core running close to a 2.0% ar pace in the last two months.
Source: European Commission, Eurostat, ECB, FSO, Bundesbank, IFO, INSEE, ISAE, Istat, INE, CBS, BNB, Markit, and J.P. Morgan forecasts

The final release from Istat confirmed that the Italian economy contracted by 0.3%q/q saar in 2Q25, following a 1.3%q/q saar gain in 1Q25. The underlying details, released for the first time, revealed a significant drag from net exports (-2.7%-pts contribution) following a surge in 1Q25, primarily driven by the frontloading of sales to the US. An increase in inventories (+1.4%-pts cont.), which had been depleted in 1Q25 to satisfy export demand, only partially offset this drag. But the weak figures were also underpinned by subdued domestic demand (+1%-pt contr.) amid elevated uncertainty and downbeat sentiment, particularly among households, despite ongoing strength in the labor market and real income growth. Private consumption (-0.2%q/q saar) has broadly stagnated after three quarters of modest growth. Meanwhile, investment remained steady (+4.2%q/q saar), as gross fixed capital formation continued to be supported by Next Generation EU investments. But it is also noteworthy that residential investment continued to hold up, increasing by 2.5%q/q saar, despite the end of the Superbonus. A rebound in government consumption (+0.7%q/q saar) also played some role in offsetting the trade drag and weakness in private consumption.

National business surveys
JunJulAugGerman IFO survey2015=100, saBusiness climate88.488.689.0Business situation86.286.587.0Business expectations90.690.790.8

The German IFO continued to increase in August, driven by an increase in the business expectation index (a component that correlates better with GDP), while the current conditions index included down. This still leaves the level of the survey weak by historical standards. The August IFO increase comes after a 0.3pt rise in the composite PMI to 50.9 last week. The PMI is our preferred measure to track GDP and this survey is broadly aligned with our 3Q \(0.75\%\) ar forecast (raised last week from \(0.5\%\) ar). Recent German GDP data were impacted by frontloading (a boost in 1Q followed by payback in 2Q) and averaged \(0.6\%\) ar in 1H. Our 3Q forecast only represents a modest momentum increase compared to 1H and we expect the German economy to expand at a similar pace in 4Q. Fiscal easing next year will be a strong boost for German growth, gradually lifting growth to a \(1.75\%\) ar pace by 2H26, in our view.
JunJulAugItaly (ISAE survey)2000=100, saProducer confidence87.387.887.4
GermanySales ex. autos and petroleum, volumes, sa%m/m-0.60.91.0%oya2.64.84.9

German retail sales fell in July. However, the latter can be noisy and prone to revision. Meanwhile, the German labour market showed a modest improvement and the PMI points to a \(0.75\% \text{aq}\) saar GDP gain in 3Q, based on July and August data.

lease from Istat confirmed that the Italian economy contracted by 0.3%q/q saar in 2Q25, following a 1.3%q/q saar gain in 1Q25. The underlying details, released for the first time, revealed a significa

The underlying details, released for the first time, revealed a significant drag from net exports (-2.7%-pts contribution) following a surge in 1Q25, primarily driven by the frontloading of sales to t

surge in 1Q25, primarily driven by the frontloading of sales to the US. An increase in inventories (+1.4%-pts cont.), which had been depleted in 1Q25 to satisfy export demand, only partially offset th

partially offset this drag. But the weak figures were also underpinned by subdued domestic demand (+1%-pt contr.) amid elevated uncertainty and downbeat sentiment, particularly among households, despi

useholds, despite ongoing strength in the labor market and real income growth. Private consumption (-0.2%q/q saar) has broadly stagnated after three quarters of modest growth. Meanwhile, investment re

has broadly stagnated after three quarters of modest growth. Meanwhile, investment remained steady (+4.2%q/q saar), as gross fixed capital formation continued to be supported by Next Generation EU inv

estments. But it is also noteworthy that residential investment continued to hold up, increasing by 2.5%q/q saar, despite the end of the Superbonus. A rebound in government consumption (+0.7%q/q saar)
